title-group.article-title: A Generalized Model for Monitoring Accounts Receivable

abstract.p: A generalized model for monitoring accounts receivable is presented. The model is an extension of the work by Carpenter and Miller (CM) [2] and it is capable of handling a wider variety of situations. The model is based on seven sets of conditions that are responsible for explaining changes in receivables. The objectives of the generalized algorithms are to measure the sales, collection, and joint effects that underlie a change in accounts receivable. The joint effects were not previously identified, and thus there were measurement errors in the CM model. The generalized algorithms provide management with information to measure the internal performance of sales and credit departments and to justify changes in credit and/or sales policies or procedures in order to control the level of receivables. Finally, the information from the model may also improve cash flow forecasting accuracy.
